natural problem: Suppose that we roll two fair 6-sided dice.  What is the probability that the two numbers rolled sum to 4?
natural solution: There are 3 ways to roll a sum of 4: 3 on the first die and 1 on the second die, 2 on the first die and 2 on the second die, and 1 on the first die and 3 on the second die. There are 36 total possibilities, so the probability is $\dfrac{3}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{12}}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B :: "nat set"
and P :: "nat set \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "finite A"
and h1 : "A \<noteq> {}"
and h2 : "B = { (a,b) . a \<in> A \<and> b \<in> A \<and> a + b = 4 }"
and h3 : "\<forall> a \<in> A. P {a} = 1 / card A"
shows  "P B = 1 / 12"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Suppose that we roll two fair 6-sided dice.  What is the probability that the two numbers rolled sum to 4? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{12}
 ### Proof
 There are 3 ways to roll a sum of 4: 3 on the first die and 1 on the second die, 2 on the first die and 2 on the second die, and 1 on the first die and 3 on the second die. There are 36 total possibilities, so the probability is $\dfrac{3}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{12}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B :: "nat set"
and P :: "nat set \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "finite A"
and h1 : "A \<noteq> {}"
and h2 : "B = { (a,b) . a \<in> A \<and> b \<in> A \<and> a + b = 4 }"
and h3 : "\<forall> a \<in> A. P {a} = 1 / card A"
shows  "P B = 1 / 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Suppose you have a set of natural numbers A. A is finite and non-empty. Define a new set B to be the set of pairs of elements from A that sum to 4. Additionally, for each element a in A, the value P for the set containing only a is 1 divided by the number of elements in A. Under these conditions, prove that the value P for set B is 1/12.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "prob_space probability"
and h1 : "indep_events (\<lambda>i. {j. j \<le> 6}) UNIV probability"
and h2 : "set_Pi UNIV (\<lambda>i. {j. j \<le> 6}) \<in> events probability"
and h3 : "{\<omega> \<in> set_Pi UNIV (\<lambda>i. {j. j \<le> 6}). sum (\<lambda>i. \<omega> i) UNIV = 4} \<in> events probability"
shows  "measure probability {\<omega> \<in> set_Pi UNIV (\<lambda>i. {j. j \<le> 6}). sum (\<lambda>i. \<omega> i) UNIV = 4} = 1 / 12"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Suppose that we roll two fair 6-sided dice.  What is the probability that the two numbers rolled sum to 4? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{12}
 ### Proof
 There are 3 ways to roll a sum of 4: 3 on the first die and 1 on the second die, 2 on the first die and 2 on the second die, and 1 on the first die and 3 on the second die. There are 36 total possibilities, so the probability is $\dfrac{3}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{12}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "prob_space probability"
and h1 : "indep_events (\<lambda>i. {j. j \<le> 6}) UNIV probability"
and h2 : "set_Pi UNIV (\<lambda>i. {j. j \<le> 6}) \<in> events probability"
and h3 : "{\<omega> \<in> set_Pi UNIV (\<lambda>i. {j. j \<le> 6}). sum (\<lambda>i. \<omega> i) UNIV = 4} \<in> events probability"
shows  "measure probability {\<omega> \<in> set_Pi UNIV (\<lambda>i. {j. j \<le> 6}). sum (\<lambda>i. \<omega> i) UNIV = 4} = 1 / 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: In a probability space where all events are independent, we consider a set of possible outcomes where each outcome is a natural number less than or equal to 6. We are interested in the probability of events where the sum of all outcomes is equal to 4. The problem is to show that this probability equals to 1/12.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes dice_1 dice_2 :: "nat set"
and Pr :: "nat set \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "dice_1 = {1,2,3,4,5,6}"
and h1 : "dice_2 = {1,2,3,4,5,6}"
and h2 : "Pr dice_1 = 1/6"
and h3 : "Pr dice_2 = 1/6"
shows  "Pr {x+y |x y. x \<in> dice_1 \<and> y \<in> dice_2 \<and> x + y = 4} = 1/12"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Suppose that we roll two fair 6-sided dice.  What is the probability that the two numbers rolled sum to 4? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{12}
 ### Proof
 There are 3 ways to roll a sum of 4: 3 on the first die and 1 on the second die, 2 on the first die and 2 on the second die, and 1 on the first die and 3 on the second die. There are 36 total possibilities, so the probability is $\dfrac{3}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{12}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes dice_1 dice_2 :: "nat set"
and Pr :: "nat set \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "dice_1 = {1,2,3,4,5,6}"
and h1 : "dice_2 = {1,2,3,4,5,6}"
and h2 : "Pr dice_1 = 1/6"
and h3 : "Pr dice_2 = 1/6"
shows  "Pr {x+y |x y. x \<in> dice_1 \<and> y \<in> dice_2 \<and> x + y = 4} = 1/12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Two dice are rolled, each with faces numbered 1 through 6. What is the probability that the sum of the numbers on the two dice is 4? The answer is 1/12.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. p n = 1 / 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> \<exists> m. m \<ge> 1 \<and> m \<le> 6 \<and> n + m = 4"
shows  "sum p {1..6} = 1 / 12"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Suppose that we roll two fair 6-sided dice.  What is the probability that the two numbers rolled sum to 4? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{12}
 ### Proof
 There are 3 ways to roll a sum of 4: 3 on the first die and 1 on the second die, 2 on the first die and 2 on the second die, and 1 on the first die and 3 on the second die. There are 36 total possibilities, so the probability is $\dfrac{3}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{12}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. p n = 1 / 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> \<exists> m. m \<ge> 1 \<and> m \<le> 6 \<and> n + m = 4"
shows  "sum p {1..6} = 1 / 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: A function $p$ is defined such that $p(n) = \frac{1}{6}$ for all natural numbers $n$. Furthermore, for every $n$ between 1 and 6 inclusive, there exists an $m$ between 1 and 6 inclusive such that $n+m=4$. Find the sum of $p(n)$ for $n$ from 1 to 6. The final answer is $\frac{1}{12}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B :: "real set"
assumes h0 : "finite A"
and h1 : "A = {1..6}"
and h2 : "B = {1..6}"
and h3 : "card A = 6"
and h4 : "card B = 6"
and h5 : "\<forall>a b. a \<in> A \<and> b \<in> B \<longrightarrow> (a + b = 4) \<in> {1..12}"
shows  "card {1..12} / (card A * card B) = 1 / 12"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Suppose that we roll two fair 6-sided dice.  What is the probability that the two numbers rolled sum to 4? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{12}
 ### Proof
 There are 3 ways to roll a sum of 4: 3 on the first die and 1 on the second die, 2 on the first die and 2 on the second die, and 1 on the first die and 3 on the second die. There are 36 total possibilities, so the probability is $\dfrac{3}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{12}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B :: "real set"
assumes h0 : "finite A"
and h1 : "A = {1..6}"
and h2 : "B = {1..6}"
and h3 : "card A = 6"
and h4 : "card B = 6"
and h5 : "\<forall>a b. a \<in> A \<and> b \<in> B \<longrightarrow> (a + b = 4) \<in> {1..12}"
shows  "card {1..12} / (card A * card B) = 1 / 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given two finite sets A and B, where both sets contain the numbers from 1 to 6. The probability that the sum of any number from set A and any number from set B equals 4, is 1 out of 12.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. i \<in> {1..6} \<longrightarrow> p i = 1 / 6"
and h1 : "p 4 = (1 / 6) ^ 2 * 3"
shows  "p 4 = 1 / 12"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Suppose that we roll two fair 6-sided dice.  What is the probability that the two numbers rolled sum to 4? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{12}
 ### Proof
 There are 3 ways to roll a sum of 4: 3 on the first die and 1 on the second die, 2 on the first die and 2 on the second die, and 1 on the first die and 3 on the second die. There are 36 total possibilities, so the probability is $\dfrac{3}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{12}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. i \<in> {1..6} \<longrightarrow> p i = 1 / 6"
and h1 : "p 4 = (1 / 6) ^ 2 * 3"
shows  "p 4 = 1 / 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: The function p(i) is defined such that for any natural number i within the range 1 to 6, p(i) equals 1/6. If p(4) equals to the square of 1/6 times 3, what is the value of p(4)? The final answer is 1/12.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. x \<in> {1..6} \<longrightarrow> P x = 1/6"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. x \<in> {1..6} \<and> y \<in> {1..6} \<longrightarrow> P (x + y) = P x * P y"
shows  "P 4 = 1/12"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Suppose that we roll two fair 6-sided dice.  What is the probability that the two numbers rolled sum to 4? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{12}
 ### Proof
 There are 3 ways to roll a sum of 4: 3 on the first die and 1 on the second die, 2 on the first die and 2 on the second die, and 1 on the first die and 3 on the second die. There are 36 total possibilities, so the probability is $\dfrac{3}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{12}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. x \<in> {1..6} \<longrightarrow> P x = 1/6"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. x \<in> {1..6} \<and> y \<in> {1..6} \<longrightarrow> P (x + y) = P x * P y"
shows  "P 4 = 1/12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Consider a probability function P that assigns the value 1/6 to each of the integers from 1 to 6. If for every pair of such integers x and y, the probability of the sum x + y is equal to the product of the probabilities of x and y, what is the probability of 4? The final answer is 1/12.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. x \<in> {1..6} \<and> y \<in> {1..6} \<longrightarrow> p x y = 1 / 36"
shows  "sum (\<lambda> (x, y). p x y) {(x, y). x \<in> {1..6} \<and> y \<in> {1..6} \<and> x + y = 4} = 1 / 12"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Suppose that we roll two fair 6-sided dice.  What is the probability that the two numbers rolled sum to 4? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{12}
 ### Proof
 There are 3 ways to roll a sum of 4: 3 on the first die and 1 on the second die, 2 on the first die and 2 on the second die, and 1 on the first die and 3 on the second die. There are 36 total possibilities, so the probability is $\dfrac{3}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{12}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. x \<in> {1..6} \<and> y \<in> {1..6} \<longrightarrow> p x y = 1 / 36"
shows  "sum (\<lambda> (x, y). p x y) {(x, y). x \<in> {1..6} \<and> y \<in> {1..6} \<and> x + y = 4} = 1 / 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given that each pair of integers $(x, y)$ with $x$ and $y$ both in the set {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6} is associated with a probability $p(x, y) = \frac{1}{36}$, find the sum of the probabilities of all such pairs $(x, y)$ for which $x + y = 4$. The final answer is $\frac{1}{12}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. x \<ge> 1 \<and> x \<le> 6 \<and> y \<ge> 1 \<and> y \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> P x y = 1 / 36"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>(x, y). P x y) {(x, y). x \<ge> 1 \<and> x \<le> 6 \<and> y \<ge> 1 \<and> y \<le> 6 \<and> x + y = 4} = 1 / 12"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Suppose that we roll two fair 6-sided dice.  What is the probability that the two numbers rolled sum to 4? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{12}
 ### Proof
 There are 3 ways to roll a sum of 4: 3 on the first die and 1 on the second die, 2 on the first die and 2 on the second die, and 1 on the first die and 3 on the second die. There are 36 total possibilities, so the probability is $\dfrac{3}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{12}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. x \<ge> 1 \<and> x \<le> 6 \<and> y \<ge> 1 \<and> y \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> P x y = 1 / 36"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>(x, y). P x y) {(x, y). x \<ge> 1 \<and> x \<le> 6 \<and> y \<ge> 1 \<and> y \<le> 6 \<and> x + y = 4} = 1 / 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: "Consider a function P that assigns a value of 1/36 to each pair of integers (x, y) such that 1 ≤ x ≤ 6 and 1 ≤ y ≤ 6. What is the sum of the values of P for all pairs (x, y) such that the sum of x and y equals 4? The final answer is 1/12."

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: real
assumes h0 : "a \<in> {1..6}"
and h1 : "b \<in> {1..6}"
and h2 : "set_pmf {1..6} = 1/6"
and h3 : "{(a, b). a + b = 4} \<subseteq> {(x, y). x \<in> {1..6} \<and> y \<in> {1..6}}"
shows  "pmf {1..6}^2 {(a, b). a + b = 4} = 1 / 12"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Suppose that we roll two fair 6-sided dice.  What is the probability that the two numbers rolled sum to 4? The final Answer is \dfrac{1}{12}
 ### Proof
 There are 3 ways to roll a sum of 4: 3 on the first die and 1 on the second die, 2 on the first die and 2 on the second die, and 1 on the first die and 3 on the second die. There are 36 total possibilities, so the probability is $\dfrac{3}{36} = \boxed{\dfrac{1}{12}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: real
assumes h0 : "a \<in> {1..6}"
and h1 : "b \<in> {1..6}"
and h2 : "set_pmf {1..6} = 1/6"
and h3 : "{(a, b). a + b = 4} \<subseteq> {(x, y). x \<in> {1..6} \<and> y \<in> {1..6}}"
shows  "pmf {1..6}^2 {(a, b). a + b = 4} = 1 / 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Two fair six-sided dice are rolled, with each face having an equal probability of appearing. What is the probability that the sum of the numbers that appear on the two dice is 4? The final answer is 1/12.
